thread.title: Why do so many people wear funny-looking blazers at Head of the Charles? - Other sports
thread.title_full: Why do so many people wear funny-looking blazers at Head of the Charles? - Other sports

author: boston.com
title: Why do so many people wear funny-looking blazers at Head of the Charles? - Other sports
text:
The Winklevoss twins model their Harvard crew blazers. F.E. Castleberry If you venture to the banks of the River Charles this weekend to watch all of the beautiful people rowing during the Head of the Charles Regatta , you may notice a number of people wearing fancy blazers. Many of these jackets will look nice and polished, but some of them will be tattered, and some of the people wearing them will look like they could go up a size or two. What’s the deal?
The blazers comes from the U.K.’s Royal Henley Regatta. It’s one of the races that every rower wants to compete in before his or her career is over. At Henley, the dress code is super formal—men have to wear blazers, and women’s dresses must be below the knee (old Victorian habits die hard, it seems).
Related Links An insider’s guide to Head of the Charles, the essential autumn-in-New-England event At Head of the Charles, boats worth $50,000 try not to crash Given the required fanciness, when college and club teams qualify for Henley they have blazers made to wear at the event. Harvard, for example, sports crimson jackets at the regatta, as modeled by the Winklevoss twins, pictured above, made famous by Facebook. If you Google “ Henley Regatta dress code ,” you’ll get a good idea of what we’re working with here.
People who’ve gone to Henley wear these blazers not just when they’re across the pond, but when they’re at other crew races and events as well, which is why you’ll see some this weekend.
But there’s a catch: As a rower, you only ever get one blazer per team or club you belong to. And you wear it to everything. So you can imagine that after several trips around the racing circuit (and ensuing parties), these articles of clothing get a little beat up. And considering what great shape these rowers have to be in when they first qualify for Henley, these blazers often don’t continue to fit as well as they once did as the years go on.
So if you see an older man walking around in a tattered jacket that he’s squeezed himself into this weekend, say congrats. He was once at the top of his game.
